nodes.diffHunk: @@ -0,0 +1,54 @@ +# Configuring a DSN on Windows + +## Test Connection + +1. Open ODBC Data Source Administrator. + + + +2. Click on `System DSN`. Select `ODFE SQL ODBC DSN` and click on `Configure`. + + + +3. DSN Setup window will open with default values for [configuration options](./configuration_options.md). + + + +4. Change values of configuration options accordingly. + +For example, if you can connect to server using following curl command + + `curl -XGET https://localhost:9200 -u admin:admin`. + + The DSN configuration options can be set as shown below + + + +5. Click on `Test` to verify connectivity. You will get a message as `Connection successful`. + + + +6. Click on `OK` to save DSN values. + + + ## Add User DSN

nodes.bodyText: Is it worth explicitly saying that if you are using an encrypted connection that the Host needs to be prefaced with "https://" rather than just implying in a picture.
nodes.diffHunk: @@ -0,0 +1,54 @@ +# Configuring a DSN on Windows + +## Test Default Connection + +1. Open ODBC Data Source Administrator. + + + +2. Click on the `System DSN` tab. Select `ODFE SQL ODBC DSN` and click on `Configure`. + + + +3. DSN Setup window will open with default values for [configuration options](./configuration_options.md). + + + +4. Change values of configuration options accordingly. + +For example, if you can connect to server using following curl command + + `curl -XGET https://localhost:9200 -u admin:admin`. + + The DSN configuration options can be set as shown below + + + +5. Click on `Test` to verify connectivity. You will get a message as `Connection successful`. + + + +6. Click on `OK` to save DSN values. +

nodes.bodyText: Let's create a low priority ticket to track enhancing this as well. Would prefer eventually that we auto-detect that encryption is enabled and take the appropriate action to make the user experience better. Not a high priority just want to track this.
nodes.diffHunk: @@ -0,0 +1,54 @@ +# Configuring a DSN on Windows + +## Test Default Connection + +1. Open ODBC Data Source Administrator. + + + +2. Click on the `System DSN` tab. Select `ODFE SQL ODBC DSN` and click on `Configure`. + + + +3. DSN Setup window will open with default values for [configuration options](./configuration_options.md). + + + +4. Change values of configuration options accordingly. + +For example, if you can connect to server using following curl command + + `curl -XGET https://localhost:9200 -u admin:admin`. + + The DSN configuration options can be set as shown below + + + +5. Click on `Test` to verify connectivity. You will get a message as `Connection successful`. + + + +6. Click on `OK` to save DSN values. +

nodes.bodyText: Added a note and created issue #726 to track this
nodes.diffHunk: @@ -0,0 +1,54 @@ +# Configuring a DSN on Windows + +## Test Default Connection + +1. Open ODBC Data Source Administrator. + + + +2. Click on the `System DSN` tab. Select `ODFE SQL ODBC DSN` and click on `Configure`. + + + +3. DSN Setup window will open with default values for [configuration options](./configuration_options.md). + + + +4. Change values of configuration options accordingly. + +For example, if you can connect to server using following curl command + + `curl -XGET https://localhost:9200 -u admin:admin`. + + The DSN configuration options can be set as shown below + + + +5. Click on `Test` to verify connectivity. You will get a message as `Connection successful`. + + + +6. Click on `OK` to save DSN values. +
